name: 03.Objective & Methodologies
content:
Objective and Methodologies


Forecast cash flows by aggregating and analyzing various transactional data like sales revenue, expense, outlays, development costs, investments


Cash flow Calculation Formula:

Cash Flow for every sale_date_month = Sum(Selling_Price) - Sum(Development_Cost) + Sum(Payment_Due_Amount) - Sum(Investment_Amount) - Sum(Expense) + Sum(Amount_Due) + Sum(Equity_Amount) + Sum(Asset_Amount) – Sum(Liability_Amount)


Method:

We have to calculate cash-flow for each organisation based on above formula.

  1. For each organisation we have to calculate month wise total sales, development cost, payment due, investment amount, expenses, equity value, asset value and liability value.
  2. Calculate cash flow using above formula.
  3. Prophet and Sarimax model are used for training
  4. Forecast the future cash flow.


﻿Features Details

Key features used:

  • Sales revenue (by product, monthly).
  • Development costs.
  • Expense breakdown.
  • Payment dues.
  • Investments, equity, assets, liabilities.
  • Derived features: net cashflow, rolling averages, ratios.

Feature Importance

  • Concept: Identifies which variables most influence predictions.
  • Method: In regression models, coefficients measure importance. In tree-based models, importance scores rank features. In time-series, lagged variables and seasonal effects are analyzed.

Model Metrics

  • MAPE (Mean Absolute Percentage Error): To assess forecast accuracy.
  • RMSE (Root Mean Square Error): To penalize large errors.
  • R² Score: To measure explained variance.
  • Directional Accuracy: Whether the model correctly predicts upward/downward cashflow trends.

IV. Data Profiling and Analysis

Data Profiling

  • Check missing values per table.
  • Distribution of numerical variables (sales, expenses, liabilities).
  • Frequency of categorical variables (expense types, equity types).
  • Outlier detection (e.g., unusually high expenses).

Descriptive Analysis

  • Summary statistics (mean, median, min, max).
  • Sales trend visualizations over time.
  • Expense category breakdown (pie/bar charts).
  • Cashflow heatmaps (monthly inflows/outflows).

Predictive Analysis

  • Forecast inflows/outflows using historical data.
  • Predict probability of liquidity shortfalls.
  • Scenario simulation (e.g., what if liabilities increase by 15%?).
  • Sensitivity analysis to determine high-impact drivers.
